column7: General Information
column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column7: Carsales.com Limited

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: Carsales' report included Auto Information Limited, Tyresales Pty Ltd, and Automotive Exchange Pty Ltd.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: Carsales' Sustainability Report provides information on the overall sustainability management and performance of carsales from 1 July 2022 to 30 June 2023.
Carsales had no restatements in 2023.
An external sampling audit was undertaken on Carsales' carbon emissions data, and Carsales worked with an external provider to validate its materiality and reporting approach.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: Carsales is one of the largest digital marketplace businesses in the world. In Australia, it has market-leading positions in the automotive, motorcycle, caravan, marine, truck and equipment industries.
Carsales had 1,808 employees in 2023.
In 2023, the health and safety system covered 100% of Carsales' non-employee workers.
Carsales' governance structure comprises the Board, the People & Culture Committee, the Audit Committee, the Risk Management Committee, and the Sustainability Committee.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: All new directors undertake an induction program, coordinated by the Company Secretary, to assist them in fulfilling their duties and responsibilities and to gain an in-depth understanding of the Group. The induction program includes one-on-one meetings with the Managing Director, Chair and Group's Executive Leadership Team members. The director must also understand the various codes of conduct and the Board and Group charters.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Mr Cameron McIntyre is the chair of the Carsales' Board.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The Board continually reviews the governance framework and practices of the Group to ensure that they meet the interests of all stakeholders.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: The directors delegate responsibility for the company's day-to-day management to the Managing Director.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column13: As an ASX-listed entity, the company has an obligation under the ASX Listing Rules to maintain an informed market in its securities. The company has a Continuous Disclosure Policy available on its shareholder website. This policy sets out the key obligations of directors and employees of the company to ensure compliance with its ASX Listing Rule and Corporations Act continuous disclosure obligations and places accountability for such compliance on directors, executive officers and employees.
column20: Continuous Disclosure Policy, security, shareholder website

column7: The Corporations Act and the company's constitution require directors to disclose any conflicts of interest and, in certain circumstances, to abstain from participating in any discussion or voting on matters in which they have a material personal interest.

Shareholders may send and receive communications to and from the company electronically. The company's shareholder website has an online contact form and contact information for relevant Company representatives.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: Each year, the Board assesses the skills and experience present on the Board and considers this alongside the desirable skills and experience to be represented.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: The company has a performance evaluation process, which is available on its shareholder website. Board evaluation involves an annual review of various aspects of the performance of the Board, including the efficacy of meetings, the quality of Board papers and reports, and the performance of the Chair, the Board and each of the Board committees.
column20: Performance evaluation, annual review, efficacy of meeting

column7: The company will seek advice from external remuneration consultants on an as-needed basis to benchmark Executive KMP remuneration against relevant peers, being ASX-listed companies that are relative in size, structure and industry to that of Carsales.

column13: Carsales has a Security Trading Policy relating to trading in the company's securities by directors, officers and other employees of the Group. This policy is available on the Company's Shareholder website. This policy prohibits participants in the Company's Employee Share Option plan from entering into transactions or arrangements that limit the economic risk of participating in the plan.
column20: Security Trading Policy, company security, Employee Share Option

column7: Carsales' annual compensation ratio in 2023 was 0.07:1.

"At Carsales, our purpose is to 'make buying and selling a great experience', and we seek to do that in a sustainable and responsible way. Our sustainability strategy focuses on the areas of most significance to our business and stakeholders, and where we can make the greatest impact. These areas are our people, our customers and our responsible business practices."

Carsales continues to drive its diversity and inclusion agenda with the support of its Diversity Strategy. Carsales' strategy places a particular focus on gender equality, given that the industries in which it operates are traditionally male-dominated.

column13: On 30 May 2023, following the Workplace Gender Equality Act 2012, Carsales submitted its annual report to WGEA. This report provides information on Carsales' policies and gender diversity numbers across the business, including Carsales' target to increase female representation to 40% on its Board by 30 December 2025.
column20: Workplace Gender Equality Act, gender diversity, female representation

column13: Carsales has a Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Policy. This policy includes requirements for the Board to establish measurable objectives for achieving gender diversity and to assess the objectives and the progress in achieving the objectives annually.
column20: Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Policy, gender diversity, measurable objective

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: Carsales has a Global Whistleblowing Policy, a copy of which is available on the company's shareholder website. The policy applies to all Group employees, contractors and eligible whistleblowers. Carsales utilises an independent whistleblower service known as the whistleblower hotline @carsales, supported by Deloitte, to maintain the highest levels of confidentiality and protection of whistleblowers.

column7: Carsales had no significant cases of non-compliance with relevant laws and regulations in 2023.
Carsales is a member of the Australian Association of Graduate Employers, Climate Active, and the Electric Vehicle Council.

column13: The company is committed to ensuring that shareholders, regulators and the wider investment community are informed of all major developments affecting the company in a timely and effective manner through the investor relations program. Information is communicated with investors in several ways, including annual reports and market disclosures.
column20: Investor relations program, shareholder, investment community

column7: Carsales has no employees on collective bargaining agreements, which is uncommon in its industry.
The Carsales Board is engaged in the company's process for selecting its material topics and the matters to be reported in its sustainability reporting.
Carsales' material topics are ethics and integrity, governance and risk management, and customer experience.

column13: Carsales' sustainability strategy helps it systematically strengthen practices essential to its ESG material focus areas. Carsales has set goals that support its efforts and provide momentum, motivation and accountability towards its achievement.
column20: Sustainability strategy, material focus area, ESG

column13: The Marketing Research and Customer Service Research Team lead Webmotors' Customer Committee. It involves more than 200 team members from across the business, often attracting at least half of the business to the meetings. The Customer Committee uses information from multiple sources, including NPS surveys, customer service data, concept and usability testing, and social network interactions, to promote customer views and measure customer satisfaction and engagement.\t
